Questions.title: What graphical technique is used to show Mendelian genetics?
Name a model organism that is used commonly in biology labs
Compare Eukaryotic cells and Prokaryotic cells, give at least three examples of differences

choices.text: Presence of nucleus, membrane-bound organelles, larger size
Lack of cell membrane, smaller size, presence of chloroplasts
Presence of cell wall, lack of DNA, smaller size

Questions.title: Describe how the loss of a cornerstone species would affect an ecosystem as a whole

Many individuals that belong to a specific species of organism die due to changing climates, while others of the same species are able to survive and reproduce. What type of selection is this, and what is the driving force behind this type of selection?
What were some tenets of Charles Darwinâ€™s Theory of Evolution, and how did he come to these conclusions? How did it compare to other theories at the time?

choices.text: Natural selection, adaptation, and common ancestry; based on observations during his voyage on the HMS Beagle; differed significantly from Lamarck's theory.
Spontaneous generation, creationism, and acquired characteristics; based on laboratory experiments; similar to Lamarck's theory.
Punctuated equilibrium, genetic drift, and artificial selection; based on fossils and genetic evidence; similar to Wallace's theory.

Questions.title: Explain how the three types of blood cells contribute to the importance of blood within the body. Give examples.

choices.text: Red blood cells transport oxygen, white blood cells defend against pathogens, and platelets help in blood clotting; examples include hemoglobin in red blood cells and phagocytes in white blood cells.
Red blood cells aid in digestion, white blood cells regulate temperature, and platelets assist in muscle contraction; examples include enzymes in red blood cells and hormones in white blood cells.
Red blood cells produce antibodies, white blood cells store energy, and platelets maintain pH balance; examples include antigens in red blood cells and glucose in white blood cells.

Questions.title: List the four major divisions of protein structure and how they interact with each other.

choices.text: Primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures; primary structure determines the sequence of amino acids, which then fold into secondary and tertiary structures, and multiple polypeptide chains may form quaternary structures.
Alpha, beta, gamma, and delta structures; alpha structure is the backbone, and beta structures are side chains, while gamma and delta structures are subunits.
Base, acid, neutral, and alkaline structures; base structure is the core, and acid structures are extensions, while neutral and alkaline structures are regulators.

Questions.title: If a book costs $20 and you have a 25% off coupon, how much will the book cost after the discount?
A train travels at a speed of 60 miles per hour. How far will it travel in 2.5 hours?
A rectangle has a length of 12 inches and a width of 8 inches. Find its area and perimeter.
If a box contains 12 red balls and 8 blue balls, what is the probability of randomly selecting a red ball?
A geometric progression (GP) has a first term of 2 and a common ratio of 3/2. Find the sum of the first 5 terms of the GP
A cylindrical tank has a radius of 4 feet and a height of 10 feet. Calculate the volume of the tank in cubic feet
